title: Two Pointers: O(n)
description: Two pointer technique on sorted array

steps.narration: The two pointer approach starts with pointers at both ends. Left at two, right at fifteen.
Two plus fifteen equals seventeen. That's bigger than nine, so we move the right pointer left.
Why? Because the array is sorted. If seventeen is too big, then two plus anything larger than eleven is also too big.
Now two plus eleven equals thirteen. Still too big. Move right again.
We've eliminated fifteen and eleven from consideration.
Finally, two plus seven equals nine. Found it in just three comparisons. That's O of n. The key insight: the sorted property guarantees we never miss the answer by moving inward.
